review_title: Growing university naturally has some growing pains
pros: Interaction with the clientele (i.e., the students) on a regular basis. You get to feel like what you do makes a difference. Friendly and supportive atmosphere generally the norm. Quiet area, low cost of living.
cons: Funding is not equally shared and can depend on how much the dean of your college likes your bosses. Nothing to do in town, so a lot of people have to travel to Greenville or Sulphur Springs for basic things like going to a hospital, an eye doctor, the movies, etc.

job_title: Children's Learning Center, Assistant Preschool Teacher in Commerce, TX
pros: The best thing is the fact that you get to nurture your passion for children. Being around children, if you have the heart and desire, is soo rewarding. Seeing them develop from when they begin at the centers as infants until the move on to the higher preschool classes is amazing.
cons: One thing that is particularly hard is when you enter a classroom, regardless of their ages, as a new teacher and see that the children have had no consistent teacher or structure. The children are basically crazy because of the lack of structure and schedule.

pros: Great work environment. Superiors are straightforward with what they expect. Very flexible and loving employers. They care about there employees and will do whatever's necessary to make sure you are happy as long as you are doing your job as an employee. Also there is always food in the break room which is always a plus. I love the culture at TRiO.
cons: None that I can think of. I have truly enjoyed working at TRiO.

pros: Research oriented, international audience, cutting edge research, friendly colleagues, and low cost living expenses. It has good number of student population that are increasing every year. There is a chance to innovate and success.
cons: This institution is located in a small university town. Apart from small happenings in the school, there is pretty much null life around the city. The nearest city is Dallas. Due to improvements, there is constant change in leadership.

review_title: Be careful taking a professorship here.
pros: The students I taught were the best part of the job.
cons:
Disorganized management, at times incompetent. 
Also, there was s focus on increasing research expectations of faculty while also increasing the enrollment numbers within classes. Universities can have one of those, but not both. It’s an unrealistic demand on faculty.
Administrators at all levels were largely concerned with enrollment numbers. This focus led to a significant to unrealistic demands on the teaching/research/service demands on faculty.  They wanted faculty to teach a lot of large classes and publish original research. These two demands are antithetical to each other.

pros: A pro of this job is that the university allows you to work while you are taking classes.  The people you work with are current students and faculty of the school, and it makes it easier to get to know more people.
cons: You are only allowed to work 19 hours a week and are only paid minimum wage.  This made it hard to pay for any sort of bills and anything extra you may need to pay for.

pros: It's a very good place to work if  you're attending university here. Helps pay for college and is a laid back environment for almost all student worker positions. You can do homework on the job
cons: The pay is pretty standard for part time work, this really isn't a con just don't expect mroe

review_title: Excellent work environment with a very understanding superior
pros:
My superiors at the math department were very understanding and accommodating 

The work load is reasonable

I felt a real sense of gratitude from my employers and their genuine kindness
cons: The biggest con I would say is the school's administration, they seem to make decisions without knowing their consequences or understanding what they are doing

their pay comparing to coast of living is ok, yet it is not that much as corporate world.

job_title: Graduate Teaching Assistant in Commerce, TX
pros: Diverse campus with a rich and varied history; beautiful new infrastructures and a great football team!
cons: I'd like to see a continued increase in campus accountability in regard to their hiring practices.

pros: PTO, health benefits and excellent retirement plan. The staff are generally good people and happy to support their colleagues when needed.
cons: Bureaucracy. You have to be liked by the right people to advance. If you don’t know how to be diplomatic, you will not survive.

pros: The only benefits would be getting TRS and other benefits of being a state employee (assuming you are lucky and your department is not outsourced). The work-life balance can be "acceptable" depending on which department you work in; some departments can be terrible in this respect.
cons:
The management of the campus is very much the "old school" buddy-buddy kind that is rampant with corruption. There have been numerous audits throughout the campus over the years for various kinds of illicit activity devised by managers. 

Multiple departments and services on campus were outsourced in a bid to make it look like the University was saving money when it came time for Systems to perform an audit. The motivation for the audit was the number of VIP level individuals the campus has as well as their unethical level of pay. VIPs on campus such as the President make enormous salaries that are unethical when you consider the cost of living and average salaries of most people in the surrounding area.

Serious job opportunities are lacking. You can find a part time job as a student, but long-term, full-time employment is limited. Additionally, even for positions requiring bachelors or masters and seeking years of experience they will routinely underpay relative to even the surrounding levels, let alone national averages. 

To advance will also require that you play the game and suck-up to corrupt management, even in cases where previously mentioned illicit activity is on-going. Many fellow colleagues have been harassed by management for making sure to follow system policy and the law instead of bending to orders from management. Some have even been harassed horribly after reporting to system auditing; the problem is that rarely is anything really done. The offending managers will usually simply be moved somewhere else on campus with a different title but still make the same money and still causing trouble.

I would highly advise anyone to pass on this place! If you do work here get out fast; staying here can and will stagnate a serious career. There are also far better places to work with more opportunity in the surrounding area. Greenville and Rockwall are much larger cities with better employment options; for your own sake do not work here!
